title: hundreds turn out to give raf ww2 bomber command hero big send off after national plea
story: George Peter Osborne, a Bomber Command Signaller in the RAF died last month at the age of  with hardly any family or friends.Sadened by the quiet send-off, the funeral director for Georges service made an appeal on Facebook, inviting the local community to gather in memory of a war hero.Funeral Director Paul Capper wrote: Dear all, I have been entrusted with the funeral arrangements of a very brave gentleman.George Peter Osborne died in Southampton General Hospital on the th January  aged  years. Sadly his executor died a month previously.Two friends are arranging his funeral for Thursday th February at The East Chapel of Southampton Crematorium at .hrs.Whilst looking through a photograph album of his it turns out that he was, according to the RAF Museum in London, a signaller in Bomber Command Air Crew.There is, so far, two people attending his funeral, is there anyone out there that could help to swell the ranks and give this brave hero who has no family a fitting send-off Today  people flooded a crematorium in Southampton, Hants, and lined the streets to pay respects to the lonely veteran.George was adopted as a child and continued to serve in the RAF before enjoying a y career as a waiter aboard cruise ships.He never married and had no children according to Georges few friends.Servicemen and women gave his hearse a guard of honour while mourners lined the crematorium driveway as his coffin was driven in.Among the well-wishers was former Sapper James Wilson, who lost both of his legs while serving in Afghanistan with the Royal Engineers.The -year-old from New Milton, Hants, said: I didnt know him, but that doesnt matter its about service brotherhood.He served on the battlefield like me, and although it was a dferent battlefield it doesnt matter. War is war.Thats why we turned up, to show our respects for another brother.If I can I always try and come to show my respects for any fallen brother who might not have many friends or family.Anyone who severed deserves a decent send-off. title: surrey struck earthquake richter scale
story: The quake was felt at .am today in the same part of the UK where a swarm of tremors hit last summer - prompting warnings that more could be in store.Seismologist Davie Galloway of the British Geological Survey said the tremors were felt by  residents this morning.We have received several reports, mainly from the RH and RH postcode areas, Surrey and a few from Crawley, West Sussex, of this event being felt, he said.Typical reports described furniture shook very gently, everything moved forwards then backwards, a loud bang and strong impact and shake as though something had fallen on the house and general rumble that lasted for a couple of seconds.He said that the tremors were part of a natural earthquake and not linked to fracking or any other similar activity.Last year special monitoring equipment was installed to better understand what is happening beneath the surface of the area after  tremors were felt between April  to October .And the latest quake at Newdigate, near Gatwick Airport, may not be the last.Mr Galloway warned: It could be the start of another swarm, or it may just be a single event. Time will tell.With the past cluster or swarm we put it down to natural seismicity. We live on a dynamic planet.Plates move about all the time. Theyre bashing and moving away from each other.He said the UK was not on the edge of a plate so did not get hit by huge quakes, but stresses could still affect the rocks.There are roughly - earthquakes in Britain every year, but the vast majority are so small that no one notices them. However between - are over . magnitude which can be felt over a wider area.UK earthquakes, particularly in Scotland, are most often attributed to glacial rebound.Until about , years ago much of the north of the UK was covered by a thick layer of ice - which pushed the rocks down into the underlying mantle.These rocks have been slowly rising back up ever since the ice melted, causing occasional earthquakes in the process.The UK is also subject to tectonic stresses caused by the expansion of the Atlantic Ocean, which is slowly pushing the entire of Eurasia to the east, and from the northward motion of Africa, which is pushing into Europe from the south.

We should stress this water is not sewerage or foul water.We have been in regular contact with Tesco who have confirmed they have arranged for work to be undertaken this week to flush out the stagnant water, and seal any pipes where it may have originated from.

title: schoolkids strike climate change demands
story: Youth Strike  Climate organisers say youngsters in  towns and cities are involved.They insist that action is needed because of “an alarming lack of government leadership” on the issue.Students are demanding the Government declare a climate emergency and take radical steps to tackle the problem.They also want the voting age lowered to  so they can influence policy.It comes after similar action in countries such as Australia and  Belgium.Anna Taylor, of UK Student Climate Network, said: “We’re running out of time for meaningful change. We’ve had enough and we’re making sure our voice is heard.”Education Secretary Damian Hinds said: “Missing class won’t do a thing to help the environment. All they will do is create extra work for teachers.”The National Association of Head Teachers said: “Nothing is more important than education.”But the strike is being supported by eco campaign groups. Green Party MP Caroline Lucas said: “This generation is taking action to build a fairer, safer world.”More strikes are due on March .

title: jihadi bride exclusion british citizenship
story: Pregnant Shamima Begum, , wants toto give birth to her third child.The jihadi bride has not voiced regrets or shown remorse for joining up with the Islamist butchers.Permanent exclusion is an option for officials, The Sun understands.Security minister Ben Wallace warned: “Actions have consequences.”Shameless Shamima Begum whined that she “could not endure any more” four years after fleeing the UK to join ISIS — but could now be banned from Britain for ever.She was just  when she linked up with the Islamist butchers in Syria.It was thought as a British citizen she would have to be allowed back.But it emerged the legal test to exclude the we of an ISIS fighter from the UK is whether she is eligible to claim citizenship where. Her parents are from Bangladesh — raising the bar to re-entry here.The Sun understands that permanent exclusion is one of three options open to officials.Alternatives are to prosecute her in her absence for being in a designated terror area — or to allow her tobut under heavy monitoring.In a brazen interview with The Times, Begum said she wanted toso the NHS could care for her unborn baby — due any day.With no sign of remorse, she claimed her “normal” le at former ISIS stranglehold Raqqa, was “the one I wanted”.She even admitted that seeing a severed head of a captured fighter for the first time “didn’t faze me at all”.Security Minister Ben Wallace issued a blunt warning to Begum. He said: “I’m not putting at risk British people’s lives to go and look for terrorists or former terrorists in a failed state.“People now want to come back to a country they actually hate  Well, actions have consequences”. Tory MPs backed the Government’s tough line.Mansfield MP Ben Bradley said: “Nobody could ever know her full and true intentions of ing to the UK, and we should not risk lives at home.”Another Tory MP, Robert Halfon, said: “I’m against her coming back because you have to give a signal.”Ministers have said they do not plan to launch a rescue mission.And there is no British consulate in Syria to support Begum.Sources indicated the Government had three main options in dealing with her.The first is to ban her from Britain permanently — stripping her of UK citizenship.The second is to prosecute her in her absence for being in a designated terror area, under new powers that came into force this week.The third is to allow the teenager toonly to then slap a strict TPIM — Terrorism Prevention Investigation Measures order — on her to closely monitor and restrict her movements.Other legal options include issuing a temporary exclusion order — used just nine times in .It bars a British citizen from coming back to the UK unless they agree to be investigated, monitored and de-radicalised.Begum’s family told how her mother wept after speaking to her on the phone.Her brother-in-law Mohammed Rehman said: “There’s a mixture of elation and sorrow.“We are happy she’s alive but sad things have come to this.“She’s put us through a lot of heartache. She’s also gone through a very dficult time herself.“Until the interview, we didn’t knowshe was alive or not. There has been no contact with her in almost two years.“Shamima’s mum just cried and told her to come home.”Mr Rehman added: “We want her to come back so she can be re-educated.“As a family we can’t understand how her head was turned like this and why she thought going to Syria was a good idea.“I can understand why people in this country are angry and don’t want her back. What she’s done doesn’t portray Islam in a good light.“She was only  when she went to Syria. We’re appealing for compassion and understanding on her behalf.”Begum is believed to be a British-born citizen, which in the past would have prevented the Government from stripping her of her nationality.Only dual-nationals or those who had become British citizens — known as “naturalisation” — could be hit with “deprivation orders” removing their UK status.EvenBegum did , she would face months of grilling by spooks and anti-terror cops. There would also be intensive monitoring with her threat assessed by MI and fed into a matrix of , “subjects of interest”.ISIS is known to have given foreign women explosives and weapons training since at least .Begum fled Bethnal Green, East London, with pals Kadiza Sultana and Amira Abase in February . The three flew to Istanbul, Turkey, before crossing the border into Syria.Sultana was killed in a Russian air strike in Raqqa aged  in . Another girl from Bethnal Green, Sharmeena Begum, now , also travelled to Syria two months earlier.It is not knownshe has survived recent bomb strikes.On arrival in Syria, Begum wed a Dutch jihadi, Yago Riedijk. They had two children. Son Jerah, died aged eight months from malnutrition in December, and daughter Sarayah died aged  months in January.Begum was living in Baghuz — under threat from Syrian Democratic Forces. She fled a fortnight ago while her husband surrendered to the SDF.Begum was taken by bus to a refugee camp in north east Syria.A Dutch anti-terror source said: “The chances that Riedijk was not in touch with members of the group planning this bloodbath is nil.“The British girl is being described as a vulnerable victim but she married an extremely dangerous man who waged jihad at home as well as in Syria.”Police smashed the Arnhem cell last year as the men were about to launch their attack.An undercover officer had infiltrated their ranks and supplied them with dummy weapons which failed to fire as police swooped.Investigators learned of their plot to use car bombs, grenades and AK assault rles at a major event, believed to be a rock festival.Their plan was to walk among innocent revellers in a line killing everyone in their path with rles and grenades before detonating a huge car bomb.Dutch police said Riedijk, who surfaced in Syria in , was one of  Muslim men from Arnhem identied as having been radicalised.Of the , six travelled to Syria where at least one has died and five have ed from the war zone.Riedijk, said to have been wounded in fighting then tortured by ISIS chiefs who branded him a spy, was separated from his British bride as they fled ISIS’s last stronghold in Baghuz.He was understood to have surrendered to a Syrian rebel group but his whereabouts were unknown.She told The Times: “The caliphate is over. There was so much oppression and corruption that I don’t think they deserved victory.“I know what everyone at home thinks of me as I have read all that was written about me online.“But I just want to come home to have my child.”There remains doubt over whether UK prosecutors could charge her.But Nazir Afzal, a former CPS chief crown prosecutor, said: “At the very least there is the potential charge of being a member of a banned terrorist organisation in IS.”He warned thatBegum ed she could face having her baby taken away by social services. He added: “If the authorities felt it fitting, the child should be taken from her.”A Whitehall source said: “Whilst Begum’sis fraught with dficulty, it would represent huge intelligence value.”Amira Abase’s dad, Abasse Hussen, , admitted that he expected his daughter to face actionshe ever ed. title: brexit vote latest theresa may brussels eu talks valentines day
story: The PM’s strategy was left in tatters on Valentines Day after more than  Brexiteers refused to back a motion of support for her, leaving it to be defeated by  votes to .Furious Brexiteers said the motion would effectively rule out Britain leaving without a deal, and destroy our negotiating hand.But she vowed to push on ahead with her Brexit plans anyway, insisting that fighting to rip up the hated Northern Irish backstop was the only thing Parliament had said they wanted her to do so far.A Downing Street spokesperson blamed Jeremy Corbyn for putting partisan considerations ahead of the national interest and voting to make No Deal more likely.They also noted the concerns of Brexiteers who voted the motion down because they thought it would effectively take away the threat of leaving without a deal.No added: The motion on January  remains the only one the House of Commons has passed expressing what it does want – and that is legally binding changes to address concerns about the backstop.The Government will continue to pursue this with the EU to ensure we leave on time on March .A total of  Brexit hardliners either abstained or voted against the motion after a meeting of the European Research Group headed by Jacob Rees-Mogg.And another  Tory MPs who back a second referendum refused to back the Government.The defeat represents the eighth time Mrs May has lost a Commons vote on Brexit and a fresh humiliation as she battles to save her deal.Critics blasted the PM for not even turning up to see the result of the showdown.Scottish Secretary David Mundell insisted the defeat was not signicant in the long term. He added: The PM still has additional time to negotiate deal revisals Parliament said it needs.He predicted the second meaningful vote would come before the end of February, when MPs will be presented with a stark choice between backing Mrs Mays deal or crashing out of the EU without a deal.As the PM still did not have a deal for MPs to vote on today she put down a supposedly neutral motion instead.It said MPs welcomed the last set of votes in the House of Commons where they forced her to go back to Brussels, but also accepted that the House didnt want to leave without a deal - something Brexiteers said was ruling out a No Deal.Steve Baker insisted the PM must now fully endorse the so-called Malthouse compromise, an alternative plan thrashed out by MPs from across the spectrum, as the only way forward.And Jacob Rees-Mogg added: The message tonight is that there is a majority for the Malthouse compromise, but the Government needs to work with its backbenchers, rather than against them.Shortly after the result Jeremy Corbyn said the vote showed there was no majority for the Prime Ministers course of action for dealing with Brexit.And he blasted: The Government cannot keep on ignoring Parliament and heading for March  without a coherent plan.Remainer David Lammy stormed: This is a Valentine’s Day massacre for the government and a damning indictment of the Prime Minister’s Brexit plan.Tory Nick Boles said he hoped the penny will now drop with Prime Minister and her Chief Whip that the hardliners in the ERG want a  No Deal Brexit and will stop at nothing to get it.Defence Minister Tobias Ellwood hit out at the Brexiteers in an extraordinary rant, saying:They caused this tonight and they are acting as a party within a party and that is frustrating.There is a deal to be decided, there is still work to be done, and yet tonight we see the ERG halting the Government, not supporting the Conservative Party. That is not necessary and its also provocative.The defeat is likely to damage Mrs Mays confidence in talks with Brussels, as they will be sceptical as to whether she can secure a majority among her own MPs for any plan at all.Steve Barclay revealed the PM will fly to Brussels next week for fresh talks with Jean Claude Juncker in a last ditch attempt to persuade them not to derail her plans.And No insisted No Deal was still on the table - but the assurances werent enough for dozens of members of of the European Research Group.Instead she just said the House welcomed last weeks votes - accepting Sir Graham Bradys change to go back to Brussels and ask for more, and a non-binding amendment to rule out a No Deal Brexit.But it was slapped down when MPs said it would effectively rule out no deal, throwing a spanner in the works of the PMs plans.CORBYN AMENDMENT - SPEED UP THE CLOCK Labour frontbenchers have proposed an amendment aimed at stopping Theresa May from running down the clock on Brexit.It would force the Government to act within two weeks, either by holding another formal vote on the PMs deal or by declaring that the deal is now off the table permanently.SOUBRY AMENDMENT - COME CLEAN Tory pro-EU rebel Anna Soubry has teamed up with other Remainers to try and force ministers to publish the advice theyve had on a No Deal Brexit.If their amendment passed, Mrs May would have to publish the most recent official briefing document presented to Cabinet on the implications of a No Deal scenario.BLACKFORD AMENDMENT - WAIT TILL JUNE Ian Blackford, the SNPs Westminster leader, is calling for a delay of at least three months to the Brexit process.Mr Corbyn also faced embarrassment as  Labour MPs defied him to back a delay to Brexit.Dozens of pro-EU backbenchers voted for an SNP amendment which would have postponed our exit by at least three months, despite being ordered not to by the leftie leader.Rejecting the motion could also make the possibility of a soft Brexit more likelythe EU decide that theres more hope of passing the dealMrs May goes into serious talks with the Labour boss Jeremy Corbyn.Hes fighting for a customs union with the bloc but Mrs May has ruled it out, saying it wont deliver on Brexit properly.Shes still in talks with Mr Corbyn but doesnt want to risk splitting her own partyshe goes for a compromise deal.The PM is trying to get her deal through by changing the Northern Irish backstop, but shes facing a huge fight with the EU to get them to agree to legally binding changes.Yesterday she was forced to deny that she was trying to run down the clock on Brexit as one of her chief negotiators was overheard in a bar saying she would offer a huge delay or her own deal.Today the Dutch PM Mark Rutte warned that No Deal would have a devastating impact on the UK, as part of a push to get MPs to back the PMs deal.

title: brexit vote remain mps plot
story: A group of senior backbenchers pledged to act like an alternative Cabinet in order to stop Britain leaving the EU without a deal.Top Tory Oliver Letwin claimed the move was necessary to avoid the terrying prospect of a No Deal outcome.But their threat to delay Brexit will anger Leave-supporting MPs who want to see Brexit happen on March  as scheduled.Speaking in the Commons today, Sir Oliver laid out a plan to take No Deal off the table by extending the Article  process.He said the rebel group would push their proposal through in two weeksMrs May doesnt strike a deal by then.Sir Oliver admitted the proposal - where the Commons rather than the Government would be dictating the path of Brexit - would be unprecedented.He said: This is a remarkable condition for Parliament and Government and the country to find itself in.It has never previously been the practice for this house to have to take control and to direct Government policy by legislation, that is an extraordinary turn of events.When this house comes to that situation we will be as it were a Cabinet... we will actually be making a decision about the future of this country.We will have in effect to take on, for this period, for this purpose, the government of this country.Sir Oliver said the proposed vote on February  would be high noon for MPs who are desperate to rule out No Deal.Yvette Cooper, who is leading the revolt, told the Commons: If we dont do something sensible like this its like were just all living in a fantasy world in which we talk about alternative arrangements.We say something is going to come along and sort it out and it just doesnt.Its aswere all standing around admiring the finery of the Emperors new clothes and actually the Emperor is running around stark naked and everyone is laughing at us - or at least they would beit wasnt so sad.The amendment would see Mrs May being set a deadline of mid-March to sign off on a Brexit deal.If she failed, MPs would then vote to delay our leaving date, giving the Government more time to get a new agreement.The PM insists that No Deal must remain an option or her negotiating position will be fatally undermined.

title: brexit what happened theresa mays
story: NewsBrexit: What has happened to Theresa Mays plan - and what happens now A House of Commons love-in just turned into a Valentines Day massacre - and it ramps up the odds of a No Deal Brexit. Heres what actually happened in tonights vote, what it means, and what happens nextShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video jeremy-corbyn-demands-theresa-face-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBrexit has been thrown into deeper chaos just  days before we leave after MPs inflicted defeat on Theresa May.  Tory rebels ganged up on the Prime Minister after what was supposed to be a House of Commons love-in turned into a Valentines Day massacre. They were holding a supposedly boring, run-of-the-mill vote to keep calm and carry on talks with the EU. But Tories who backed Mrs May two weeks ago threw out her strategy in a row over whether she is ruling out No Deal. Also, to add insult to injury, she was forced to back down and publish secret papers that show the impact of leaving on March  without agreement.  Tonights vote wasnt legally binding. But it fundamentally weakens Theresa May at the moment of maximum danger. So what has actually happened - and what will happen next  Here is a quick guide.  MPs held a vote on whether to reiterate backing for Theresa Mays Brexit strategy - which they agreed two weeks ago. Back in January, they agreed to send her back to Brussels to renegotiate the backstop - a clause in her eal which could trap the UK under EU customs rules from  January . Yet this time, the Prime Minister lost by a majority of  after MPs voted - against her motion. Why, you ask  Its all about tricky wording. MPs were being asked to reiterate support for the approach to leaving the EU expressed by this House on  January. The problem is, that approach had two parts. The first was changing the backstop, which Tory Brexiteers support. But the second was to reject the idea of a No Deal Brexit - which Tory Leavers say must stay on the table. So they revolted en masse.  abstained on the motion and another  voted against - which left an open goal for Labour to defeat it.  Tonights vote is not legally binding. But it massively weakens Theresa May just as she is trying to put up a united front against Brussels. The PMs been through the mill the last few months. On January , her -page Brexit deal suffered the heaviest defeat in Commons history. Finally, on January , she won a glimmer of hope. MPs actually agreed on something - thatshe changes the backstop, theyll pass her deal. Coarsing with adrenaline, the battle-hardened Prime Minister seized this vote with both hands. She marched back to the EU and demanded changes to her deal - saying she finally had Parliament on her side. But now its clear she doesnt have Parliament on her side. Instead, what she called a substantial and sustainable majority for her plans has slipped away. It exposes her, and her fragile parliamentary maths, leaving her naked just as she was meant to be marching in armour-clad with the EU. Tory ministers were pretty clear about how damaging itd beshe lost. Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay warned EU leaders would be watching the votes for any sign our resolve is weakening. We should not give them that excuse not to engage, he said.  In the short term, arrogant Theresa May vowed to completely ignore the Parliamentary defeat and carry on regardless. The stubborn PM was not even in the House of Commons for the humiliating vote. Jeremy Corbyn demanded she come face the music, saying: Tonight’s vote shows there is no majority for Parliament for the Prime Minister’s course of action. But minutes later, Downing Street released a statement attacking Jeremy Corbyn and proclaiming she will continue to pursue talks with the EU. It means cross-party talks with Labours leader, who had offered to back Mrs Mayshe supports an EU customs union, look dead in the water. Further talks between the Prime Minister and the EU, though, are planned for later in the month.  In the longer term, the Prime Minister is in huge trouble. All this debate is counting down to a final meaningful vote on her revised Brexit deal in the House of Commons. In recent days, its emerged she could push this back as far as March  - four days before we leave the EU. And MPs are absolutely determined to stop this blackmail. Jeremy Corbyn warned: She cannot keep on just running down the clock and hoping that something will turn up that will save the day. And SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford demanded she put the meaningful vote before Parliament next week. MPs will hold another string of votes on February , where they could vote to delay Brexit or back a second referendum. That date is now being trumped as the high noon - the moment where Theresa May could have her arm twisted into abandoning her reckless plan or holding an early vote. The problem is, what will MPs actually vote on  The EU has made clear its not going to budge on that Northern Ireland backstop. She wants a time limit, exit clause or alternative arrangements. But its looking like the best she can hope for is some keyhole surgery, inserting brief words of assurance or guarantee into the -page Brexit deal. If this isnt enough for MPs, then boy, howdy - shell be really stuffed.  Does it make No Deal Brexit more likely  In a word, yes, it looks like it. Ian Wright, Chief Executive of the Food and Drink Federation, said: “The defeat of the Government motion tonight will increase fears among food and drink manufacturers that there is now a diminishing prospect of rescue from the catastrophe of a ‘no-deal’ Brexit.” Labour MP Stephen Doughty of the Peoples Vote campaign said: Time is running out for Parliament to hold a meaningful vote on her Brexit deal andthere is no majority for it in the House of Commons then the only responsible way forward is to give the final say back to the public with a People’s Vote. PS: What ELSE happened tonight   There were a series of dferent votes tonight. Completely separately, Theresa May agreed to publish secret No Deal Brexit advice to avoid a Commons defeat. The Prime Minister caved to Tory rebels after they demanded to see a supposed official briefing document handed to the Cabinet. Mrs May had argued a Cabinet briefing, which MPs said showed the implications of No Deal Brexit on business and trade, was private advice and should not be published. But she said she would to cave to MPs demands after they threatened to put it to a vote tonight. InTory rebel Anna Soubry - who had led the cross-party bid - withdrew a Commons amendment that would have handed over the document. Meanwhile, Labour failed in a bid to stop Theresa May running down the clock and force a vote on her Brexit deal by February . MPs defeated Jeremy Corbyns amendment - after Tories refused to support it. And an SNP bid to delay Brexit by at least three months failed by  votes to  - despite a rebellion by  Labour MPs.

story: NewsTory minister says treacherous Jacob Rees-Mogg should join Nigel Farages partyBusiness minister Richard Harrington lashed out at members of the hard-Brexiteer European Research GroupShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical CorrespondentShaun Connolly:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video jacob-rees-mogg-nigel-farage-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Tory minister has sensationally accused Brexiteer MPs from his own party of treachery - and said they should join Nigel Farages new party. Business minister Richard Harrington lashed out at members of Jacob Rees-Moggs European Research Groupof Eurosceptic Tory backbenchers. He suggested members should defect to Nigel Farages new party because they are not Conservatives. Referring to the ERG, the minister told The House magazine: The Prime Minister has done a pretty good job of standing up to them up till now, but they were drinking champagne to celebrate her losing her deal and I regard that as being treachery.   He added: I read that Nigel Farage is setting up a new party called  Brexit  andI were them Id be looking at that, because that seems to reflect their views more than the Conservative Party does. They should read carefully what that partys got to offer, because in my view theyre not Conservatives. There are people who are very solid and stringent in their views andI were they I would be looking at a party that seems designed for them - Nigel Farages party. Mr Harrington, who backed Remain in the referendum, said it would give the ERG pleasureministers who shared his views onBrexitresigned.   He said: If we all resigned what would then happen  If I were in the ERG, it would give me a lot of pleasure to see us resign. But we cant give in to a minority of a minority, which is what the ERG are. Mr Harrington also dismissed the so-called Malthouse compromise, which is intended to try to bridge Tory isions onBrexit.   The minister said: Its basically regurgitated Canada Plus, which we know is not at all suited to our close relationship with the European Union, plus a bit of gloried number plate recognition kit, which theyve got there anyway. I think its just fancul nonsense. story: NewsMum of Alesha MacPhail defendant called cops after spotting him half naked on night girl diedA -year-old boy, who cannot be named, has denied abducting, raping and murdering Alesha MacPhail and claims the crime was committed by Toni Louise McLachlanShareByElaine McCahillAssistant News Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsAlesha MacPhail suffered catastrophic injuries, the court heard "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCCTV footage shown to a jury shows the boy accused of Alesha MacPhails abduction, rape and murder leaving his house three times on the night she died. Instead, footage showed her son leaving and ing to the property on three occasions throughout the night. The -year-old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, denies raping and murdering Alesha, as well as charges of child abduction and defeating the ends of justice.  He has lodged a special defence of incrimination stating Ms McLachlan, the partner of Aleshas dad Robert MacPhail, committed the crime. Alesha was reported missing by her grandmother, Angela King, at .am on July , and the child’s body was found at the site of an abandoned hotel on the Isle of Bute just before am that day. During the fourth day of proceedings, the mother of the accused gave evidence and told of how her son was clever, popular and well-liked in school. The accused had lots of friends, was good at maths and did parkour, she told the court. The mother of the accused said she was aware he had been smoking cannabis from the age of  but wasnt really that bothered about it. The accused’s mother told the court her son held a post-exam party on the night before Alesha disappeared. She said the pair had an argument on the night and her son was very drunk and angry.  The accused had drunk a bottle of wine and Mad Dog , she said. He was very angry because his -year-old sister had left the house with his friends. The last of his friends left around .am and he remained in the house, she said. She said she tried to get him to phone his sister before going to bed She also explained a video security system had been installed in the house because a family member with dementia was moving in. The jury were shown footage of them rowing at .am on  July,  - the night Alesha went missing. She and her son can be heard shouting and swearing at each other. The accused’s mother went to bed and said she was awoken at .am to shouting in the street as people looked for Alesha.  After checking the back garden she woke up her son and askedhe knew anything about Alesha’s disappearance. He replied no and went back to sleep. She then went out with her dog and joined the search where she met Alesha’s family and reassured them everything would be OK. The accused’s mum said she checked the CCTV in her home after hearing about Alesha’s disappearance. She sawthe accused ing home around am and was unaware he had left the house.She had been looking at the footage to seeAlesha had walked past the house.  She then went further back in the CCTV to discover her son left in the direction of Rothesay town and passed Robert MacPhail’s home. He ed from a dferent direction and had a shower. He left again wearing only shorts and carrying a T-Shirt and jumped over a wall. He did not have any shoes on. He came back seven minutes later. When she asked what he was doing he told her he did not know and was maybe looking for his mobile.She said she noticed his feet were dirty.  She confronted him about leaving the house and recalled him saying: I dont know, I mustve been looking for my phone. But when asked by advocate depute Iain McSporran QCthat puzzled her, she replied: Yes. The accused’s mother said she decided to phone the police about the CCTV after speaking to a friend. She told her friend her son had been out of the house when Alesha disappeared. She told the police about the CCTV because she thought it would eliminate him from their enquiries. The mum said: But I didn’t think he had actually done anything, it was more to help the police and eliminate him from their inquiries. The court was then shown footage from .am which she said she assumed was him leaving for the first time.  The court was then shown footage of a person arriving back at the house at .am. The mother of the accused said she assumes it is her son. He jumps over wall and enters rear of house. CCTV shows the bathroom light coming on. Footage shows the accused leaving the property again wearing just shorts. A third clip, which the accuseds mother said she was not aware of is shown to the court.It shows the accused ing to the house before sprinting out again with what looks like a torch. At :am he s home again, now walking. The trial continues.

title: alesha macphail neighbour spotted man
story: NewsAlesha MacPhail: Neighbour spotted man carrying little girl on his back on CCTVA -year old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, denies abducting the schoolgirl from her grandparents Isle of Bute home, raping and murdering her and attempting to hide evidenceShareByLaura Paterson:,  FEB NewsAlesha MacPhail "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA neighbour of Alesha MacPhail saw somebody carrying a child on CCTV hours before the six-year-old was reported missing, a court heard. Alexander McLachlan, a welder, said he contacted police after making the discovery on the cameras fitted to his home in Marine Place, Rothesay. The -year-old said the footage, from .am on July , and shown to the jury, resembled somebody carrying something on their back. There was movement coming from the shelter, then somebody walking asthey were carrying something on their back, he said. Once he knew a child was missing, he told police he presumed the person walking was carrying a little girl. His sister-in-law Shari Strathie, , said CCTV from her home next door, also shown in court, featured a person carrying something on their front with legs hanging down.  The jury was also told today that Alesha had been smothered and suffered catastrophic injuries to her genital area. Pathologist John Williams said the youngster had more severe injuries to that part of her body than he had ever seen before. Alesha had a total of  separate injuries, he said. The High Court in Glasgow was shown graphic images of these, which judge Lord Matthews warned were distressing. A -year old boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, denies abducting the schoolgirl from the home her grandparents shared with her father on the Isle of Bute, raping and murdering her and attempting to hide evidence. Her body was found in a wooded area on the island on July  last year.  Dr Williams said his post-mortem examination of her body indicated the cause of death was signicant and forceful pressure to her neck and face. He said the injuries to her neck and face were consistent with being gripped and those to her nose and mouth were consistent with smothering. He added it was also possible her was windpipe pushed shut. Most of the the  injuries were caused by the nature of the ground she was lying on, the jury was told. Her injuries included tears to her private parts, one of which essentially obliterated part of her genital area and were consistent with severe and forceful inflicted penetration, which could have been caused by a body part or object. Advocate depute Iain McSporran QC asked him: Have you ever before seen injuries of these sort to the private parts  Dr Williams replied: No.  The pathologist said the soles of her feet were clean, consistent with her being picked up or otherwise taken to where she was found. Questioned by Brian McConnachie QC, for the accused, who described Aleshas injuries as catastrophic, Dr Williams said he had never been shown an object that could have caused them. The court also heard from the accuseds mother, who said her son had been drinking with friends at home early on July . She said they argued about damage to furniture and then she thought he had gone to bed. The following day she helped search for Alesha and later checked her CCTV system covering the front and back of her home had lived with her, and saw her son on the footage. The court was shown footage in which she identied her son leaving the home at .am on July , wearing all black, and ing at .am no longer wearing his black top. At .am, a light is turned on in the bathroom and he is seen leaving a minute later wearing only shorts and carrying an item.  He leaves the house again at .am, running off wearing shoes, shorts and a top before ing at .am. The mother said she told her son about the footage and asked him why he was out, to which he said: I dont know, I might have been looking for my phone. She asked himhe knew anything about the missing girl and he said no. His mother later phoned police to eliminate her son from inquiries, saying: Obviously I really didnt think he had anything to do with it whatsoever. After the police spoke to him she said he told her he was first out looking for cannabis and later for his phone. She said: I talked to him and tried to explain that whoever had done this to this little girl their DNA would be all over her. He was adamant, absolutely adamant, that he had nothing to do with it. There was no way they would find DNA on this little girl because he hadnt seen her and he hadnt been with her.  She was later shown pictures of a kne found on the shore, which she said is very similar to those in her kitchen but she had no idea how it got there. His mother was also shown jogging trousers and boxers at the shore, which she said looked like her sons. She described her son as clever at maths, well-liked and said he had lots of friends. The accused has lodged a special defence blaming Toni McLachlan - the girlfriend of Aleshas father Robert MacPhail - for the killing. During her evidence to the court on Wednesday she insisted she had had nothing to do with the girls death, telling jurors: I loved her to pieces. The trial continues.

title: benefits cash could saved lives
story: NewsopinionBenefits cash could have saved the lives of Angela Smith - and thousands moreDonald Smiths daughter Angela took her own le believing her payments were being reassessed - then her dad received a cheque from the DWP for benefits underpaid to Angela of £.ShareCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist:,  FEB NewsopinionAngela – a gentle soul who had suffered since childhood with severe mental health problems "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAngela Smith, a gentle soul who loved birds and nature, took her own le in  believing her disability benefits were being reassessed. She was already struggling to survive on the money she received due to a letime of severe mental health problems. This week, three years after his daughter’s suicide, Angela’s father, -year-old Donald Smith, received a cheque from the DWP for pound.. A letter said that Angela had, in fact, been underpaid by around pound a month from  to . Donald, now , says the money – around pound a month – “for Angela could have been the dference between le and death.” He adds that fears about money were “one of the principal reasons Angela took her own le.” The DWP says Angela was underpaid due to an “administrative error”.  The betrayal of Angela comes as the Labour Party launch a hard-hitting party political broadcast blaming a shameful , deaths on Tory austerity. The film, aired for the first time on Wednesday evening, says Tory cuts and NHS privatisation have caused a “national emergency”. The film explicitly links pound billion of cuts to health and social care and falling le expectancy and excess deaths in England. Donald first wrote to me in November , then aged . A heart-breaking letter enclosing the order of service from his daughter’s funeral. His beloved Angela, he said, had taken her own le after being told she faced a benefit reassessment, and having local psychiatric support withdrawn.   He has always blamed the DWP and austerity for Angela’s death. He also blames multiple failings by the now notorious Southern Health NHS Trust. At the time of her death, Angela’s case was even raised in Parliament by Luciana Berger MP, then shadow minister for Mental Health. “Do these people, the government ministers like Iain Duncan Smith, the pen pushers and bean counters, realise the misery and even death they are causing ” Donald says now. “Do they even care  I doubt it. It’s a lousy system that needs scrapping.” Donald’s comments come as a DWP minister, Sarah Newton claimed it is ‘shameful’ to claim benefit cuts have driven people to suicide. Sarah Newton accused critics of “deliberately misusing data” to say Tory welfare reforms are driving people to death. Meanwhile, James Cleverly, Deputy Chair of the Conservative Party, called the Labour broadcast “shameful scaremongering”. “They’re still at it now,” Donald says, talking about grandfather Jeff Hayward who this week won his appeal against being found fit for work – seven months after his death.  Mr Haywood had died in June after spending the last  months of his le battling for disability benefits. His family say the stress of his appeal and financial problems caused contributed to his death from a heart attack at the age of . Angela had been on the disability benefit ESA since August , but faced reassessment – which used to happen every two years – in . Before she died, she had spoken to her dad about friends facing similar problems who had recently taken their own lives. “This is the way they are trying to get rid of us, Dad, and for everyone that takes this way out, they probably open another bottle of champagne’,” she told Donald. Donald, a former factory worker, had spoken to his daughter on the Sunday before she died, and only realised later that she hadn’t ended the phone call with her usual “I love you, Dad”.  Now he says: “A more glaring example of how the benefits system’s gross inadequacies and mismanagement can impact profoundly on people with mental disabilities would be hard to find. To say it’s ironic, hardly covers it.” The Work Capability Assessment – or fit-for-work test – he says, “is long overdue to be scrapped”. The DWP says: “We want to ensure people receive the support they are entitled to and apologise for the error which resulted in Miss Smith receiving less in ESA support then she should have. We have paid full arrears to her family.” Meanwhile, partly because of cases like Angela’s ESA and Universal Credit Work Capability Assessments are no longer given to disabled people with the most severe and lelong conditions. Adding to her distress, Angela had recently been told she was no longer eligible to access mental health services she relied on, provided by Southern Health.  That is the same Trust linked to deaths including that of -year-old Connor Sparrowhawk, who drowned in the bath at a residential unit in their care in . Donald had been to her GP to beg for help, warning his daughter was suicidal, but to no avail. Donald is still unhappy with Southern Health’s report into Angela’s death, and the Trust remains in dialogue with him. Over three years since we first spoke, Donald has also lost his beloved we, and at  and in ill health himself, is still battling for answers. Knowing another , people have lost their lives to Tory austerity cuts responsible for brutal welfare reforms and decimated services, brings him no comfort.

title: girl 3 found crying without
story: NewsGirl, , found crying and without underwear after wandering half a mile from nurseryBrooke Masterton managed to slip away from the playground of her nursery in Evanton, Scotland, and crossed two main roads and a bridgeShareByHayley Coyle:,  FEB News "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA toddler was found crying and missing her underwear half a mile from her nursery after escaping from the playground, her outraged mother has claimed. Little Brooke Masterton, three, managed to cross two main roads and a bridge before she was found sobbing in her grandparents garden by a neighbour who then took her back to nursery. Her terried mum Nicole said she feared her daughter had been abducted when she found her knickers in the garden of her parent’s home in Evanton, in the Scottish Highlands. But in fact, a distressed Brooke had wet herself so removed her knickers and tights and left them in the garden.Nicole, , told The Daily Record : I was livid. I couldnt even speak. I was shaking with anger.“My head was absolutely spinning. I couldnt understand it. Why were Brookes pants there and she was nowhere in sight. So much was going through my mind but the one major thing was someones got her. “Brooke could have been killed or hit by a car or abducted. Theres no security over there and now Im being told by Highland Council that they cant put in some better security.She dropped Brooke off at Kiltearn Primary School s nursery at am as normal and went to help her elderly parents with their shopping.But when she got back to her parents’ house just before pm the scene before her left her frozen with fear.  Nicole said: The pants and tights Id put on Brooke were lying in the middle of the garden. I ran over and picked them up and they were all wet...shed peed herself. Nicole ran straight to the school and demanded to know where her daughter was. I was shaking, I ran in and said ‘wheres Brooke . The secretary lady told me Brooke is in class. She said staff told her Brooke had gone missing from the playground. “It was explained that a neighbour who lives next-door to Brookes grandmother on Thomas MacIver Street found her crying in the garden and had taken her back to school. Nicole said: I couldnt believe what I was hearing. Brooke was crying and saying mummy I couldnt find you. I was shaking horribly. It was clear to me that someone had obviously turned a blind eye in that playground. Who in their right mind would allow a child to get out of their sight in a nursery playground    “Brooke had to cross two main roads and a bridge across a river to get up to my mothers. She might not have been here today. Every time we walk that road to nursery she tried to climb up the frame of that bridge. Imagineshed have done that that day without me there to stop her  Nicole said she phoned the police who investigated but concluded that it was a council matter. The mum-of-three claimed the only reason she was breaking her silence was because the council had turned down her request for better security at the nursery which is attached to the school. And she is keeping the little girl back from starting school this year unless security measures are put in place. I cant put here into P this year because of it because I do not feel it is safe. I can’t put her into a playground knowing that she can get out of it. Its just horrible.   Parent council chairwoman Annelie Graham said security was a concern”. She said: “The front entrance to the school was going to be completely overhauled and that was promised in November and it was going to be done by Easter-time. “Then we were told it was still to be confirmed butit has been shelved then we are going to make an official complaint. It’s something that does need to be sorted and it is a concern. A Highland Council spokeswoman was unable to say whether anyone had been disciplined over the matter because the authority does not comment on personnel matters.

story: NewsMum defends decision to get -year-old daughter bikini body readyHayley Sinclair, , said there is "nothing wrong" with getting children to work out moreShareCommentsByCharlotte Nisbet:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video mum-gets-bikini-body-ready-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who said theres nothing wrong with kids getting beach body ready has defended training with her daughter since she was just . story: NewsPrince Harry giggles at shrine in Arctic igloo - including photos of MeghanPrince Harry got a bizarre surprise when he entered a shelter in Norway to meet British troopsShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  FEB NewsPrince Harry is in Norway - where he saw an unusual shrine "Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The Duke of Sussex didnt spend Valentines Day with his we Meghan Markle , but she wasnt far from his mind. The Duke, who is Captain General of the Royal Marines, is visiting Exercise Clockwork to mark  years of the Commando Helicopter Force and Joint Helicopter Command.The troops in Norway are taking part in one of Britains biggest war exercise against Russia in  years, as a warning to Vladimir Putin over his continued agression.A source said: Prince Harry will be totally immersed in the exercise and he will be privy to top-secret battle plans. story: NewsUK climate strike: Schoolkids STRIKE in fear for planet theyll inheritPupils stand with banners outside Ulla­­pool Primary School in the West Highlands of Scotland to raise awareness of global warmingShareCommentsByAmanda Killelea:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsFinlay Pringle with his friend Megan on the left and his sister Ella on the right in their activism over climate change "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFor weeks Finlay Pringle has been putting down his pencil and walking out of school for an hour on Fridays. But the -year-old isn’t playing truant – he is striking in protest at what he sees as government inaction on climate change. Finlay, his sister Ella, nine, and their friend Megan Ross have braved wind, rain and snow to stand with banners outside Ullashyshypool Primary School in the West Highlands of Scotland to raise awareness of global warming. They were inspired by Swedish schoolgirl Greta Thunberg who protested outside parliament in Stockholm over politicians ignoring the issue. Her stance captured the imagination of young people worldwide, sparking demos from Australia to Canada. And today thousands of pupils across the UK will follow Greta and Finlay’s lead by walking out of school as part of Youth Strike  Climate.   Finlay says: “Politicians aren’t getting the message. I don’t see the point of being educated for one hourhighly educated people aren’t listening to us. What is the point of us planning for our futurethere isn’t going to be one  “I want politicians to listshyshy-en to the scientists. They are the ones who know what to do but they are being ignored because of Brexit . “Our head and my teacher are fully supportive but I don’t think all teachers think it is a good idea.” Pupils from more than  towns and cities including London, Manchester, Lanshyshycaster, Sheffield, Leeds, Camshyshybridge and Truro will join the demonstration, part of a movement sweeping the globe.  North London A-level student Anna Taylor, , is one of the organisers. She says: “I value my education and I am disappointed and angry I am having to miss school but I have no option. We aren’t old enough to vote and it is a matter of letting the Government know that young people care. “We thought we might get  people in London at best. We have been astounded by the response.” Emma Greenwood, , from Ramsbottom, Lancs, is travelling to Manchester to join the protest.   She says: “We need to start taking responsibility for what we are doing to the environment. “My future is in danger and the Government needs to realise that.” The strikes pose a dilemma for heads. He says: “Greta’s stand has started a bandwagon and extremists are now climbing on board. “The kids are being led by the tune of environmental pied pipers. They will be driven from the protest in polluting cars munching burgshyshyers made of methane-emitting cattle and chatting on phones built from extremely rare minerals. “For many it will just be the chance to bunk off and have a laugh.” But Finlay’s dad, fisheries officer Jeff, , is supshyshyportive. He says: “People of my genshyshyeration have had our opshyshyshyportunity to do something and we failed miserably. “So I don’t think we should be too surprisedyoung people of the world decide it is up to them to get it sorted.” Pupils demands The UK Student Climate Network have put together a list of four demands: . That the Government declares a climate emergency and prioritises the protection of le on Earth. . Reforms to the national curriculum to address the ecological crisis as an educational priority. . That the Government informs the public about the need to act on climate change. . And that the Government recognises that young people have the biggest stake in our future by lowering the voting age to . Climate change in numbers - According to NASA, the Earth’s average surface temperature has risen .F since the late th century. Most of the warming was in the past  years, with the five warmest years since . - The Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets have decreased in mass. Greenland lost an average of  billion tons of ice per year between  and , while Antarctica lost about  billion tons in the same period. - The rate of Antarctica ice mass loss has tripled in the last decade. - In the last  years, sea levels have risen approx  inches.

title: buy one get one free set sail with the tele on a luxury cruise to norway and the scottish isles departing from dundee
story: Tele readers will be able to enjoy the best sights Norway and Scotland have to offer when the paper sets sail on its very own cruise adventure.The exclusive Tele voyage on the majestic Magellan cruise ship  will depart on a nine-night tour around some of the most breath-taking scenery in the world.With up to , passengers, the glamorous ship will visit awe-inspiring fjords and some of Scotland’s stunning islands.A convenient departure from the Port of Dundee means you can look forward to leaving the hassles of airports behind and get straight into holiday mode.The journey evokes nostalgic memories of the days when The Tele#s parent company ran a famous shipping line in the s.There will be plenty of entertainment on board as well during the special trip # all organised by The Tele#s owners DC Thomson and ship operator Cruise and Maritime Voyages.Fresh delights will await every day as a dedicated team of expert chefs and attentive restaurant staff serve up delicious meals and a luxurious evening dining experience with up to five courses.Magellan, named after the great explorer Ferdinand Magellan, offers an incredible iety of activities within its ftframe, including a show lounge, pubs, coffee shops, casino and shopping galleria.The Tele Magellan voyage departs from Dundee on June  , and arrives back in Greenock  days later # after taking in sights including Flam, Bergen and Portree.While best known these days for its industry-leading publishing work, DC Thomson has a long and proud association with the sea.Following his success in business, William Thomson II looked to the seas and purchased a stake in a sailing ship.His involvement escalated over the years when he purchased more vessels.Eventually, with a fleet of , the Thomson family was responsible for one of the most invaluable shipping firms in the world and provided essential aid to South Africa during the Boer War.Andrew Thomson, chairman of DC Thomson, said: “It’s wonderful to see DC Thomson realigning with its heritage by ing to the seas.“When William Thomson established the Thomson Shipping Line in the th century I’m sure he didn’t contemplate that over  years later DC Thomson would be transporting passengers by ship around the Scottish Isles and Norway.“This kind of ersication of the business is a great fit for DC Thomson.”Craig Houston, head of enterprise for DC Thomson Media, said: “Working with Cruise  Maritime Voyages to bring this highly desirable sailing route to DC Thomson Travel customers has been a pleasure.“We’re excited to be offering such a special route with a trusted partner and we can’t wait to hear what our passengers say about this amazing trip.”

title: dundee uniteds mark connolly impressed with quality at tanandice as club unites
story: Recent recruit Mark Connolly believes Dundee United added real quality in the January transfer window but insist there is no “them and us” between the new arrivals and the players who were already on the books.The former Crawley Town and Kilmarnock defender says the aim of getting the Tangerines back to where they belong in the Premiership will be achieved through a group effort.The experienced Irishman has turned in two highly-impressive performances against Morton and St Mirren since his deadline-day arrival.And fellow-new men like Peter Pawlett, Mark Reynolds and Cammy Smith have also shone in those victories.The -year-old is quick to point out that, while the spotlight has been on them, the team as a whole has earned the recent success.“Dundee United is a very big club and, unfortunately, we’re in the league where we don’t want to be,” he said.“That’s the reason why myself and quite a few others have come in to help the boys already here and move up and get back to where we should be.“We are here to add to the players already here because, on top of all the boys who’ve just come in, we have very good players here.“We’ve only trained a few times together but you can see the quality that’s here and I think the manager has added just that bit more bite to help the football club.”Connolly realises the changes manager Robbie Neilson made in January means it is going to take a while for the players to get to know each other’s games inside out.It’s a process, though, that has been done while winning games and, under Neilson, he believes that can continue to be the case.“There have been a lot of changes but we are professional enough to handle that.“Sometimes it’s an excuseyou don’t start well and say we’re a new team and will need time to gel.“We don’t have the time to do that and we have brought in players who have experience and quality.“The manager has been dferent class – he’s a top-quality manager and deserves to be in the top league.“Myself, the new boys and the boys already here can help him get there.”Performances like the weekend Scottish Cup success at the Buddies will help.Connolly feels it’s one that will have had others sitting up and taking notice.“First-half we did what we know we can do. Being on the pitch it certainly felt it could have been a lot more than - at the break.“We dominated the game and that gives you a bit of confidence, especially playing against a Premiership team.“Second half we knew St Mirren were going to come out and have a bit more about them.“They did, but we were dealing with it without any real problems.“Unfortunately for us, Calum Butcher got sent off when it was a - tackle in midfield and could have just been a yellow card.“But he got sent off and then we showed the character to stick in and win the game.“We were playing against a team from the level above us for about  minutes with  men. We rolled our sleeves up and got the result we deserved.”

title: far travelled dundee star ryan mcgowan says scots footballers are luckier than they think
story: Far-travelled Ryan McGowan believes Scottish footballers don’t realise how lucky they are as they make their way in the game without having to give up their home comforts.When the -year-old signed for Dundee on loan from Bradford City at the end of last month, it took his tally of clubs in a -year senior career to .And having turned out for outfits in his native Australia, Scotland, China, the United Arab Emirates and England during that period, he’s clocked up more air miles that your average long-haul airline pilot.Having always known he’d have to travel round the world to make a career in football, the Socceroo believes it’s made him more open to hop from one country to another.That, he’s learned, is in contrast to many of the friends he’s made here in Scotland.“Scottish kids probably don’t realise how lucky they are. They’ve got something like  full-time clubs within a three-hour drive of where they’ve grown up,” he said.“When I was growing up in Adelaide, we had one team and then it was a two-hour flight to the next closest.“Soyou weren’t good enough for that team, you had to work harder and be prepared to sht around.“I know boys here who only want to play for teams in or near Edinburgh – and they can.“Scottish boys are very lucky to have so many clubs and opportunities without having to move.”While he’s no regrets about his nomadic career, McGowan admits the chance to hang around in one place for a prolonged period is growing more attractive.Particularlythat place is here in Scotland, the country he regards as his adopted home.“I do sometimes think I’d love to sign a two or three-year contract somewhere again,” he added.“I would have probably have loved to have stayed on at Hearts for a couple of more seasons and I was enjoying my time at United when I was there but bids came in and were accepted.“And having an Australian passport does open doors in Asia, which is why I’ve ended up there a few times.”If the chance arises to stay at Dundee long-term, he admits it’s something he will give serious thought.He has not, and will not, look that far ahead until he’s helped the Dark Blues out of their current predicament.“A couple of weeks ago moving to Dundee hadn’t even come onto my horizon. Everything has happened quickly and I just want to make sure that, first and foremost, we stay in this league.“When the summer comes,an opportunity arises to stay I will definitely consider it but there is a lot of work to be done between now and then.”He is confident by the end of the season Dundee will be safe.“It’s been really good so far. They are a great bunch of boys and they have made me feel really welcome in the dressing-room.“I’ve kicked most of them when I was playing here in seasons gone by so I know most of them.“There’s a good manager in Jim McIntyre to work under as well. I’m showing my age here but I’ve actually played against him when I was a young player on loan at Ayr from Hearts.“He was coming to the end of his career then and later I played against a couple of his teams once he’d become a manager.“I’m quite close with a couple of players who have played under him and they spoke highly of him and that was more of a factor in coming here.“Having played across the road I also knew how big a club Dundee is. It’s a good club, in a dficult position at the minute but definitely one we can get out of.”

title: george cran dundee are in a far better place now than when jim mcintyre arrived
story: Almost four months into his reign as Dundee manager, Jim McIntyre won’t look back on his first match in charge with too much fondness.However, he might just do so with a great deal more satisfaction with how his squad has shaped up in the time since.Despite only picking up two wins and six draws in the  matches under McIntyre, there’s a growing sense of optimism at Dens Park after some encouraging displays since the January transfer window.The opposite can be said of Saturday’s opponents Livingston, the side the Dark Blues faced in Jim’s debut in the dugout.After a lightning-fast start to theirto the Premiership – which peaked with that - thumping of Dundee back in October – Livi’s form has slipped off a clf with last Wednesday’s - draw at Hearts bringing a five-game losing streak to an end.Since leaving Dundee gaffer Jim in no doubt how big a job he had on his hands with that - success at the Tony Macaroni Arena, Gary Holt’s side have only picked up three victories and none since the middle of December.That’s seen them slip from a high of second spot with  points from their first eight games down to ninth with just  picked up from the following  matches.And, though the gap between the sides hasn’t shrunk in those four months, the feeling around both clubs right now couldn’t be more dferent.A massive part of that from Dundee’s point of view is the complete overhaul of the playing squad in the winter transfer window.In fact, there’s a fair chance there won’t be any of the players who featured in the - defeat the last time the Dark Blues travelled to West Lothian this time around.Only three of the  used by Jim that day remain at the club – Elliott Parish, Cammy Kerr and Kenny Miller.Of those, only Miller looks like he could be given a start this time around but even he has a fair bit of competition to overcome with Andrew Nelson on the goal trail and Craig Curran preferred by the manager to lead the line in every match since he arrived at the club at the start of January.A missed penalty in stoppage time in their last run-out won’t have helped veteran Miller’s cause either.Meanwhile, Parish hasn’t featured since that - thumping and doesn’t look like dislodging Seny Dieng as first choice any time soon.The nature of the goals that day, with all four from set-pieces, no doubt led the manager to question his defenders.Parish quickly paid the price by dropping to the bench while three of the back four have been moved on.Andy Boyle is now at Ross County, Ryan Inniss was sent back to Crystal Palace after a nightmare at Palmerston in the Scottish Cup and Calvin Miller has also dropped to the Championship, being picked up by Ayr United on loan from Celtic.Kerr was right-back in October but he’s seen his place taken by new signing James Horsfield in recent games.The former Manchester City kid has looked assured in Kerr’s place and will take some shting before Saturday.The rest of the team have since been shown the exit door – Glen Kamara, Kharl Madianga, Lewis Spence, Sofien Moussa, Benjy Kallman, Roarie Deacon and Adil Nabi have all moved on.Even the side that drew - with Livi at Dens on Boxing Day will be unrecognisable to the one running out this weekend.Whatever side he opts for, Jim knows his team are in a far better place than when he took over – now they have to prove that by getting points on the board.

title: tom duthie this time the renewed hope at dundee united might not be a false dawn
story: For the first time in a long time, perhaps even since the dark days of relegation in , there is strong reason for optimism at Dundee United.The one thing that should be stressed about that immediately is it’s still early days.Robbie Neilson’s rebuilt team is only two games in and that means there is some way to go before we can confirm things are definitely on the up at Tannadice.And the truth is that will only come with promotion back to the Premiership.It must also be said there have been other  dawns over the past three years.The arrival of Ray McKinnon and then Csaba Laslo as managers brought hope and even early promise that, after the disastrous   campaign, things were being turned around.In fairness to McKinnon in particular, had he been handed the kind of budget that was made available to the current team boss in the January transfer window, the major problems at the club might well have been sorted and the Tangerines could have been back in the top flight already.Unfortunately for him, those in the boardroom when he was in charge were unable to provide the kind of cash for signings new American owner Mark Ogren has.That, incidentally, is not a criticism of the previous regimes, just an unfortunate fact.Neilson has been lucky he’s got an owner with dollars to spend and the indications so far suggest that owner is just as fortunate that he has a manager who knows how to spend it wisely.Ogren can also consider himself blessed his predecessor in the chairman’s seat at Tannadice, Mike Martin, found not just a good manager, but one who through being out of the game for a period, had taken the time to look at United and form a clear picture of what was needed.Because one thing that’s obvious about the signings made is all have been part of a jigsaw in the manager’s mind.January  didn’t just come round and see Neilson turn his thoughts to what was available. He’d done his homework and, equally importantly, worked out exactly where his squad needed strengthening.That means the right players for the right positions have been found, or so it seems.That’s produced victories over Morton and St Mirren that have lted spirits among Arabs. Rightly so, because both outings have seen impressive work.Of course, with most of those brought in lacking match fitness – that’s usually the major issue with January signings – the good football, has mostly come in the first hour.Players who’ve not had a lot of game time have tired, particularly when reduced to  men at St Mirren. They’ve then shown their ability to manage matches.What the manager also looks to have done well is identy those already in his squad who were good enough to be part of his plans.For all new boys like Peter Pawlett, Mark Reynolds and Mark Connolly have deserved the praise they’ve received for their first couple of performances, attackers Pavol Safranko and Nicky Clark have shown they remain big players.After a run of just two goals in nine games, Safranko has found his scoring touch with one in each of the last two outings and has looked the lethal striker he did when he first arrived on loan from Aalborg.Now he’s finally got fully fit, Clark also looks dangerous and there’s no doubt both have benefited from having better players round them in the last two outings.For Neilson and his players the trick is now to keep the good work going. The good news for United fans is, this time, that might just happen.

title: Council agrees budget for 2019 20
story: It says thebudget is set to deliver pound. million savings over the next three years with a "Change Fund" of pound. million set aside to help "resource and deliver the change programme".Investment of an additional and recurring pound. million for roads maintenance was also approved, with plans for how this will be spentto be brought to a future meeting of the councils development and infrastructure committee.Members also agreed to raise Council Tax by three per cent.Budget leader, Councillor Alister Mackinnon, said: ldquoOur workforce is vitally important to communities. Not just in the services they provide, but, as one of the biggest employers in Highland, council jobs are fundamental to the sustainability of many communities. So a budget for jobs is really good news for people.ldquoA key element of the feedback we received is that we have many cumbersome, complicated and bureaucratic processes. We need to do things dferently, streamlining processes, be more outward looking and adopt best practice.ldquoAn overwhelming message is that we need to be more efficient. Basically, we need to get a grip on our expenditure. As a result we have been examining every budget line and turning over every stone, to make sure that we are getting the best results from the resources being used and challenging where performance can be improved.ldquoIf you always do the same things in the same way, you will get the same results. It is time to change how we do things and so this is a budget for change."The change fund is an exciting element of our budget strategy and will underpin our programme of change over the coming year.Council leader Margaret Davidson said: ldquoThis is a decent, thoughtful and ambitious budget which will help move us into the future, protecting jobs and services."It aims to set the council on a journey of much needed change. We are all ambitious for improvement and what has struck me is the huge buy-in from all staff in challenging circumstances.ldquoThis budget will enable us to be sustainable and I am really confident that we have the necessary knowledge and expertise in our top team to take forward the change programme that is required.Chief executive Donna Manson added: ldquoThis budget process has been about us being connected. Connected to our communities, to our staff, to our partners, to each other ndash building relationships and enabling better conversations and improved understanding.ldquoI really appreciate the input from staff across the organisation during the whole engagement process, and for some really honest feedback. I am equally delighted with the really positive engagement across the political groups.ldquoWe need to manage all our resources, to redesign, to become more resilient, to be more efficient, to invest in our workforce and to plan for the future. We need to embed effective performance management and effective scrutiny.ldquoThe Corporate Plan will be coming to council in March and this will focus on scrutiny and driving performance. It will underpin the work of the council moving forward, ensuring that we use all our resources to the best effect ndash and the engagement with communities and staff will be a continuing process throughout the year.
