title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Friday  Feb  : AM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Friday  Feb  : AM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Friday  Feb  : AM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Friday  Feb  : AM

title: Prince Harry set to attend Mey games
story: THE Mey Highland Games is going to ldquoput Caithness in the global spotlight, according to its organiser Captain Richard Otley, after Prince Harry announced he would attend the event this year.Rumours were re last year that Harry and his we Meghan would attend the special event which included para-athletes for the first time but when the royal retinue appeared at pm there was no sign of the couple.Capt Otley believes that the information released over the weekend to the media about Prince Harryrsquos attendance may have come from Buckingham Palace itself. He was unable to confirmMeghan would attend along with her husband, but said it would be ldquotruly fantastic for Caithness and help put it on the mapthe royal couple turned up.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will welcome their first child this spring.Friday  Feb  : AM

title: This weeks Caithness Courier
story: Due to circumstances beyond our control, this weekrsquos edition of the Caithness Courier wonrsquot be in the shops until Thursday morning. We apologise for any inconvenience but this was due to a combination of problems with our contract printers and distribution partners.Friday  Feb  : AM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Friday  Feb  : AM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Friday  Feb  : AM

title: Wick Francis Street Club placed in liquidation
story: WICKS Francis Street Club has been placed in liquidation, it was confirmed on Thursday.According to provisional liquidator Iain Fraser, a partner with FRP Advisory, the decision was made following a decline in membership, rising costs and unsustainable cash-flow problems. The club ndash founded in the s as a British Legion ndash has now closed and six staff have been made redundant.Mr Fraser said: "The Francis Street Club has been a landmark social, entertainment and sports venue in Caithness for nearly  years. Sadly, the club has been suffering severe financial problems and liquidation was the only option available to the committee."We are working closely with the relevant agencies, including the Redundancy Payments Office, to ensure the staff receive as much support as possible. We are now offering the assets of the business for sale, including the building, fixtures and fittings, and would urge interested parties to contact our Aberdeen office as soon as possible on   ."The Francis Street Club started was a long-established social, entertainment and sporting venue which attracted some well-known names through its doors, including former world snooker champion Stephen Hendry who staged an exhibition match there.It served as a social club and ran both football and darts teams, both well supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.The premises closed last month. At the time, a statement issued by the club said: "It was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , ."A note subsequently posted on the door read: "We have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course."Friday  Feb  : AM

story: newsInteractive HIE roadshow comes to OrkneyFebruary ,  at : pm vw, px"  Starting here in Orkney this week, Highlands and Islands Enterprise is hitting the road to teach people how to outsmart online criminals and spot cyber threats.The free Cyber Sense on Tour workshops will visit businesses and communities throughout the Highlands and Islands using fun, interactive games to allow participants to get under the skin of hackers and learn the tricks of the trade.The tour starts in Orkney with two events, the first at Orkney Library this Tuesday, February , and the second at the NorthLink ferry Hamnavoe at the Stromness terminal on Wednesday.The interactive experience is open to all and will use innovative technology to create an immersive ‘point of view’ exercise, were participants can take the role of an employee, a cyber security professional and even a hacker to learn the tricks of the trade.Concepts such as ‘phishing’ will be explained and audiences will be taught to spot scams, dissect spurious emails and prevent hackers taking over their online lives.Working in collaboration with the National Cyber Security Centreand supported by the Scottish Government, the Cyber Sense sessions will provide a memorable and engaging way to discover how everyday actions can help protect people and companies from these evolving cyber dangers.April Conroy, project manager at Highland and Islands Enterprise, said: “As the way we work and live becomes more integrated online, it can be easy to take for granted how much important information we upload to the internet. Whether it’s our personal information on social media or important financial details, it’s vital that we’re aware of how to keep our safe and secure from cyber criminals.”“By really getting under the skin of these hackers, our Cyber Sense workshops can point out how to understand how these iniduals work. Through the games we’ve designed, attendees will be able to competitively play roles on both sides of a cyber-crime. This offers a unique perspective that can show just what preventative measures can be taken to outsmart these online criminals.”To learn more about the Cyber Sense on Tour event and to book a free place, visit www.hellodigital.scot cyber-sense- copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: power cable fault results in rackwick work
story: A faulty power cable, which links Orkney with mainland Scotland, has resulted in work being carried out at Rackwick Bay in Hoy.A Scottish and Southern Energy Networks spokesman said: “SSEN can confirm there is a network fault affecting one of the two electricity distribution cables that connect Orkney to the Scottish mainland. Following a fault investigation process, damage has been located to a section of the Pentland Firth East cable near the shore at Rackwick Bay, Hoy.“There is no impact to customer supplies on Orkney as a result of the fault and contingency measures are in place, including the potential operation of the backup power station at Kirkwall, supported by mobile generation sets, to ensure a safe and secure supply of electricity for customers.“SSEN is committed to ing the network to normal operation as soon as possible and has instigated a repair plan. Following the receipt of the necessary permissions from statutory authorities late last week, work to undertake a sectional cable replacement is now under way.#The statement added: #It is expected this work, which will be contingent on tidal flows and weather conditions, will be complete early next week, with the line re-energised shortly after.“As part of SSEN’s subsea cable inspection and replacement programme, a project to progress an end-to-end replacement of the Pentland Firth East distribution cable is already at an advanced stage of development, with cable installation and commissioning currently due to take place in autumn next year.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: survey project sheds new light on hms royal oak
story: A VOLUNTEER e team has been granted permission to extensively survey the official wargrave of HMS Royal Oak in Scapa Flow.New D photogrammetry techniques are being used and still photography and videography will allow the team to capture and share the spirit of the site.In the early hours of October , , U’s commander Günther Prien guided her silently into Scapa Flow, and launched a torpedo attack, In just a few minutes, Royal Oak was gone.  sailors perished, including over  boy seamen.Ahead of the th anniversary of her loss later this year, a team of volunteer civilian ers has been granted permission to e the wreck by the secretary of state for defence.This is part of a collaboration with the Royal Oak Association and the Royal Navy to document the last resting place of the men who lost their lives, so their passing can be remembered and preserved for future generations.The project aims to ensure that HMS Royal Oak is not forgotten, by sharing imagery with relatives of those lost, as well as the wider public.The survey team is using state-of-the-art underwater imagery techniques, in order to produce high-quality photography and video. In addition, D photogrammetry is taking place so that digital D models of the wreck can be produced. By using these techniques, in essence, the team is able to digitally bring HMS Royal Oak to the surface.Survey organiser and licence-holder Emily Turton said: “The wreck of HMS Royal Oak is the final resting place of  men and boys. As the most intact underwater dreadnought-era battleship, she has an architectural grandeur befitting of any national memorial. However, at the smaller end of the scale, artefacts pertaining to everyday le on board are scattered around the site, bringing home the human story of those lost. The site is peaceful, yet vibrant, and supports a thriving marine eco-system. It is both an honour and a privilege to get to know the site.”Full details and further pictures in The Orcadian this week.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: Council agrees budget for 2019 20
story: It says thebudget is set to deliver pound. million savings over the next three years with a "Change Fund" of pound. million set aside to help "resource and deliver the change programme".Investment of an additional and recurring pound. million for roads maintenance was also approved, with plans for how this will be spentto be brought to a future meeting of the councils development and infrastructure committee.Members also agreed to raise Council Tax by three per cent.Budget leader, Councillor Alister Mackinnon, said: ldquoOur workforce is vitally important to communities. Not just in the services they provide, but, as one of the biggest employers in Highland, council jobs are fundamental to the sustainability of many communities. So a budget for jobs is really good news for people.ldquoA key element of the feedback we received is that we have many cumbersome, complicated and bureaucratic processes. We need to do things dferently, streamlining processes, be more outward looking and adopt best practice.ldquoAn overwhelming message is that we need to be more efficient. Basically, we need to get a grip on our expenditure. As a result we have been examining every budget line and turning over every stone, to make sure that we are getting the best results from the resources being used and challenging where performance can be improved.ldquoIf you always do the same things in the same way, you will get the same results. It is time to change how we do things and so this is a budget for change."The change fund is an exciting element of our budget strategy and will underpin our programme of change over the coming year.Council leader Margaret Davidson said: ldquoThis is a decent, thoughtful and ambitious budget which will help move us into the future, protecting jobs and services."It aims to set the council on a journey of much needed change. We are all ambitious for improvement and what has struck me is the huge buy-in from all staff in challenging circumstances.ldquoThis budget will enable us to be sustainable and I am really confident that we have the necessary knowledge and expertise in our top team to take forward the change programme that is required.Chief executive Donna Manson added: ldquoThis budget process has been about us being connected. Connected to our communities, to our staff, to our partners, to each other ndash building relationships and enabling better conversations and improved understanding.ldquoI really appreciate the input from staff across the organisation during the whole engagement process, and for some really honest feedback. I am equally delighted with the really positive engagement across the political groups.ldquoWe need to manage all our resources, to redesign, to become more resilient, to be more efficient, to invest in our workforce and to plan for the future. We need to embed effective performance management and effective scrutiny.ldquoThe Corporate Plan will be coming to council in March and this will focus on scrutiny and driving performance. It will underpin the work of the council moving forward, ensuring that we use all our resources to the best effect ndash and the engagement with communities and staff will be a continuing process throughout the year. I look forward to getting back out to see staff from next week onwards.Friday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Dingwall sale brings lots of joy to charities
story: CHARITIES which help Highland cancer patients in their time of need will share a pound, windfall from a special auction in Dingwall.The event at Dingwall Auction Mart had originally been put together to raise funds for Beauly mother-of-two Roz Paterson who had been aiming to secure pound, to fund potentially le-saving treatment in the United States,Her condition has proved resistant to several forms of chemotherapy leaving her facing a race against the clock to try and access expensive Car-T cell therapy in Boston.When it emerged that her treatment will now be funded on the NHS much closer to home, a decision was taken that the mart auction would go ahead ndash with four key Highland charities benefiting instead.Supporters of the Raising for Roz campaign had come up trumps with more than  lots put forward.The go-ahead for the auction provided a welcome boost for Highland Hospice, Marie Curie, MacMillan Nurses and Maggiersquos Highland.The star lot was a wedding package worth pound, which was snapped up by Inverness couple Alison Ireland and Christian Kenway for pound.Auction organiser Willie Matheson hailed the full-house auction a great success. He said: ldquoThe star lot was the wedding package which was quite unique and went to a local girl. That meant a lot to us and a lot to me especially.Friday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Dingwalls Nordic past to live again through trail
story: VIKING culturersquos key role in Dingwallrsquos history could soon be highlighted by a long-awaited heritage trail around the town ndash thanks to the efforts of enterprising residents.The Dingwall Community Development Companyhas already enjoyed considerable but muted success as the recently formed group continues to build membership and go after funding.So far DCDC has funnelled pound of cash from the Gough Charitable Trust to revamping the seating and paths at popular Ferry Point on the shores of the Cromarty Firth. But after holding the first AGM last week, the group now wants to go after larger projects through the lottery funding.The ultimate ambition is to renovate Dingwall Town Hall and ensure it is brought into regular and sustained use by locals and visitors as a focal point of the town.Before that, the DCDC directors and trustees, comprising Janet Bowen, Debbie Downie, Robin Lingard and Nigel Greenwood have been ldquosting through the communityrsquos suggestions for improvements to the town.Mrs Bowen said: ldquoDingwall is very fortunate to have a number of organisations which are dedicated to making the town an attractive and welcoming place. But we want to use our charitable status to unlock funding for capital projects which should make a signicant dference in raising Dingwallrsquos profile.The first of those projects out of the traps has been developed with the help of the Dingwall History Society and is a heritage trail around the town which stops off at around a dozen sites.Among them are the memorial next to the train station, the birthplace of MacBeth ndash Dingwall Castle, as well as the Macdonald Monument and others.Mrs Bowen said: ldquoUsing a series of display  to highlight to both local people and visitors the richness of Dingwallrsquos history, especially as a Viking settlement.A sticking point however is that the bridge over the Dingwall canal is closed due to safety concerns.ldquoThe big issue here, of course, is the future of the footbridge across the Dingwall canal, which has been out of use for some time now because of safety fears. The community council is very anxious to bring it back into use and we are looking at what role we might play in helping to bring it back into use.Many local groups feel that Dingwallrsquos Viking heritage has been a little neglected but in  archaeologists and historians managed to flesh out the legends. They confirmed that the townrsquos Cromartie car park was the site of a Viking parliament or meeting place ndash called a lsquoThingwallrsquo ndash from which Dingwall get its name.Friday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Glenmorangie taps into global demand with new developments
story: AN historic Easter Ross distiller intends satisfying a global thirst for its drams with a multimillion-pound development at its Tain base.Work by Morrison Construction on a new still house and additional mashing and fermentation facilities is now under way at Glenmorangiersquos plant. The new still house will showcase two more of the firmrsquos signature copper stills, the tallest in Scotland.A separate building using reclaimed stone salvaged from distillery warehouses will provide the additional mashing and fermentation facilities. Two new warehouses are also under construction.A Glenmorangie spokesperson told the Journal: ldquoOur new still house, as well as the additional mashing and fermentation facilities, will position Glenmorangie for ever-greater success and ensure that the distillery can continue to satisfy the worldrsquos growing appetite for our award-winning single malt Scotch whisky.ldquoThis year we have added new management and engineering roles at the distillery and once operational, the expansion will create two additional roles.Its drams are perfected by the ldquoMen of Tain, who have passed their skills down the generations. title: Highland seafood firm goes into liquidation
story: A Highland seafood firm set up by an award-winning entrepreneur has gone into voluntary liquidation.Coast and Glen, founded by Magnus Houston in , had grown rapidly in recent years, supplying fresh fish and game to hotels and restaurants across the UK and had also expanded direct sales to consumers.The business, which employed nine people and had a turnover of pound. million, operated from fully-fitted leased premises in Alness and had also acquired a new  sq ft factory in Muir of Ord.Its liquidation was attributed to unsustainable cash flow problems stemming from rising costs, intense competition and very low margins.Mr Houston, a former motorcycle racer, taught himself the trade after a bad crash.His other business, Fishbox, is unaffected.Friday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Parents asked to play their part in dealing with Alness disorder
story: PARENTS in an Easter Ross town are being asked to ensure they know what their children are up to at night following spates of antisocial behaviour which has spurred a fresh police crackdown.Officers say they have spoken to a number of young people in Alness in the presence of their parents following the incidents, which have also prompted an appeal from a local councillor.Police Scotland Easter Ross community policing Inspector Jamie Wilson said: ldquoI would like to thank the local community for their patience whilst we investigate these incidents.ldquoI appreciate that behaviour of this nature is alarming, however I would like to reassure local residents that we are working closely with schools, High Le Highland and partners to reduce and prevent further antisocial behaviour.ldquoWe continue to investigate incidents which have been reported and are following positive lines of enquiry. Those involved will be identied and will either be reported to the procurator fiscal or issued with a Recorded Police Warning as appropriate.ldquoWe will also be issuing parents with antisocial behaviour letters highlighting the conduct of their children in the hope that they may be a positive influence before things escalate.ldquoOver recent weeks we have spoken with several youths regarding their conduct in the presence of their parents. In the main the response has been positive and I would appeal to parents in Alness to support the community by knowing what their children are doing each evening. We will continue to target our resources in the area to address the behaviour of those involved.Backing police action, Councillor Pauline Munrosaid: ldquoThese incidents have caused concern to local residents, particularly where property has been damaged.ldquoI would urge parents to be aware of what their children are up to during the evenings and to discuss where they are going.Nicky Grant, head teacher at Alness Academy, said: ldquoWe are working in partnership with Police Scotland to ensure that our students and parents feel supported, informed and engaged at this time.Anyone with information should contact Police on  or Crimestoppers on  you would prefer to remain anonymous.Back in November, we reported how youth workers in Alness had appealed to people to share concerns with them and also appealed to parents.Friday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Parents blast council for not seeking cash to fix crumbling Dingwall school
story: SOME of the most vulnerable pupils in Ross-shire have been treated with "utter contempt" by the local authority which has misled parents and failed to seek "a single penny" of extra cash from the Scottish government.That was the damning indictment this week ahead of a crunch meeting on the future of St Clements in Dingwall before Highland Council sets its budget.Members of the parent-teacher council have already written to every single councillor urging them to take long-promised action to resolve severe problems with school building declared unfit for purpose by the governments childrens minister.The Scottish Government has confirmed the local authority has not sought funding for St. Clementrsquos from the the Scotland Schools for the Future programme.The next tranche of the pound billion announced last November will only be available from  leaving teachers and pupils enduring years more hardship in a building branded "Dickensian" by local MSP Kate Forbes.A Scottish government spokesman said: ldquoWe have been made aware that St. Clementrsquos is in poor condition, however it is the statutory responsibility of Highland Council to manage and maintain its school estate.ldquoThe Scottish government has provided signicant funding of over poundm in recent years towards five projects through its existing school building programme, Scotland Schools for the Future, all of which were Highland Councilrsquos priority projects for investment. Highland Council has not asked the Scottish Government for support in relation to St Clementrsquos.Christyna Ferguson, whose daughter suffering a series of complex health issues including autism attends the school, slammed the councilrsquos inaction "utter contempt for the already disadvantaged, vulnerable children".She said: "The Highland Council repeatedly told us that St.Clementrsquos appalling lack of facilities was due to a lack of Scottish government funding. Therefore it is misleading at best and shows not only non-compliance with their statuary obligations but utter contempt for the children."In the last year the Highland Council has taken no action to survey sites, secure funding or build a business plan despite assuring us they would."She insisted: ldquoHighland Council does have options in terms of funding solutions but they repeatedly refuse to engage in the process ndash again failing in their statutory obligations and causing unnecessary suffering and detriment to disabled children. It is incomprehensible to me that those with the power and the obligation in law can show such blatant disregard for disabled children."Dingwall-based MSP Kate Forbes said: "As the daughter of a former teacher at St Clementrsquos, I am in no doubt as to the poor condition of the buildings. It is remarkable the teachers are able to care for and teach the pupils in such a damp, cramped building.ldquoThere is a desperate need for a new building, delivered in consultation with parents and teachers. This is, of course, a matter for Highland Council who are statutorily responsible for school buildings but I think everybody wants to see a solution."I am more than happy to work with anybody and everybody to find a solution and would sincerely hope that wersquore not still talking about school buildings in another  years."Childrenrsquos minister Maree Todd, also a Ross-shire-based SNP MSP, said: "The school has not previously been prioritised by Highland Council in their capital spending plans despite being in a poor condition."Itrsquos nearly a year since I first raised concerns with the council so I look forward to meeting with councillors and officers at the end of this month to hear an update on progress. All children, especially those who are disadvantaged and vulnerable, deserve our help to enable them to, not only fulfil, but to exceed their potential. That is why it is vital that we can find the right solution for the pupils, parents and the wider St Clementrsquos community.A Highland Council spokeswoman said: "At this point in time we are addressing our capital plan for next year and the process is still ongoing. The council has been in dialogue with Scottish Government and highlighted the  school locations, including St Clements, which were identied by the council in March  as priorities for bids to Scottish Government. We are not aware of any Scottish Government Funding prior to ."Friday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Stone
story: Highlighting the "great historic good" the European Structural Fund has brought to Ross-shire, Easter Ross MP Jamie Stone said: "It paid for new airports, roads, economic development and tourism.ldquoWhen I asked the Prime Minister what would replace this she referred me to the Shared Prosperity Fund. We are very scant on the details of a Shared Prosperity Fund."Could I respectfully ask the Prime Minister to ask officials to meet with myself and other interested members of parliament to discuss what this fund might be and how it might apply to areas of the UK such as my constituency.Mrs May said she is currently in the process of consulting on the nature of the Shared Prosperity Fund and the criteria within which it will work "so I will ask relevant officials to meet with the honourable gentleman in the way he has requested",Mr Stone though said afterwards: "It is clear that there is nothing concrete about a Shared Prosperity Fund. This was the third time I have asked for details on the proposed replacement funding and for the third time I have not received an answer."The Highlands cannot rely on hypothetical funding and Theresa Mayrsquos lack of clarity shows she is aware leaving the EU will make my constituency worse off.ldquoThis comes as it is estimated that the Highlands and Islands would have been entitled to approximately pound million in EU funding between -.ldquoLeaving the EU, particularly crashing out as Theresa May seems to be advocating, would be a disaster for my constituency."I am elected to represent my constituentsrsquo interests and given the shortfall in funding that the Highlands would face in the case of Brexit, I cannot support anything that will make them worse off.Your view  Email newsdesk@spp-group, leave a comment or write to us at the address on our letters page.Friday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Strathpeffer author pays tribute to charity that was there to help
story: A STRONG-WILLED Strath-peffer author who lost her sight aged  has paid tribute to the Highland charity that got her through the hardest days of her le.Emily Gray descended into misery after the  diagnosis, but said Sight Action showed her how to be happy again.The -year-old, whose childrenrsquos book Priscilla the Pig has just hit the shelves, said the support from the Inverness-based team was transformational.ldquoThey were brilliant, they changed my le, she said. ldquoIrsquove gained confidence to do everything.Miss Gray lost her sight when she was just  due to problems brought on by Type  diabetes.Looking back on the experience, which forced her to drop her music degree at Edinburghrsquos Napier University, Miss Gray, who now has a guide dog called April, said: ldquoI was in limbo. I didnrsquot do anything. I couldnrsquot go out by myself. It was not a nice place to be in...I was just existing and no more. All the hopes I had for the future were gone. I just felt like I had lost everything.The mum-of-one was referred by a specialist to Sight Action and the charityrsquos rehabilitation worker Brenda Smart became her strongest ally.The -year-old who is also the organisationrsquos client service manager was bowled over by Miss Grayrsquos resolve.ldquoWhen I first met her, I thought lsquothis is quite a determined young ladyrsquo. There were times when she doubted herself, but she put everything into it.Mrs Smart said cooking skills were important for Miss Gray.ldquoI showed her how to weigh out the recipes and all the things thatyoursquore sighted you do without thinking about it. Even the tidying up a bit, sweeping the floor, vacuuming. I showed her how to do that with a grid so she can tellshersquos got most of it up.ldquoAnd when she was pregnant we took out a baby doll and practised putting the baby in the carrier and changing the nappies on the doll. And when Harris was born she was absolutely brilliant. Irsquom really proud of her.Book publisher James Houghton of Olympia Publishing said: ldquoWhen considering the work, I was not aware Emily was blind. She is a great example of not letting a disability stand in your way.During pregnancy, Emily, who writes under the pen name Madeline Rose, mused over her own childhood and settled into writing her first story inspired by her mumrsquo Heatherrsquos tales of le on a farm in Dingwall using a voiceover computer programme.It is illustrated by self-taught Nairn artist, Sarah Jane Cumberford.Friday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: scottish council supports ban on go large takeaway promotions
story: A Scottish local authority has signalled its support for a ban on #go large# promotions on meals in cafes, restaurants, and takeaways as part of attempts by the country#s food watchdog to tackle the nation#s poor diet.Councillors in Dundee, which has the worst obesity rate for primary one-age children anywhere in mainland Scotland according to NHS Scotland figures, is expected to formally back plans to introduce mandatory measures to address the obesity crisis. The body responsible for food standards and nutrition in Scotland is currently consulting on a range of proposals, including mandatory calorie labelling. Food Standards Scotland has said the country’s diet is too high in calories, fats, sugars, and salt, which can lead to type  diabetes, heart disease, and cancer. Now, Dundee City Council’s community safety and public protection committee is expected to formally endorse the watchdog’s suggestions, stating that “mandatory means” are necessary to address problems which cost Scotland £.bn a year. In its draft consultation response, the committee said it wants to make outlets serve smaller portions and print the calorie contents of meals on menus.A report to councillors, who will be asked to formally approve the response at a meeting on Monday, states: “There is no single solution to tackling the issue of a poor diet, however eating outside the home is one of the areas where change is needed as in many cases the food and drink on offer tends to be a less healthy option.”The council’s response argues that as well as compulsory calorie labelling, food inspectors should be trained to carry out checks to ensure premises are meeting the new regulations. It states: “Businesses need to cease practices that encourage over-consumption.“This will require defining carefully which practices encourage overeating. Multi-packs and ‘go large’ promotions on meals and drinks should be banned. Healthy meal deals could be promoted.”: Restaurants could face curb on portion size and calorie countIt added that “public sector premises should be exemplars and early adopters” of the new measures.Alan Ross, the convener of the committee, said: “Basically, we are trying to promote healthier lestyle choices.“It’s about people living longer, reducing the strain on the NHS and the benefits eating healthily.”NHS Tayside dietetic consultant in public health nutrition Joyce Thompson said: “NHS Tayside is aware that food eaten outside the home currently makes up a signicant part of people’s diets and therefore welcomes the Food Standards Scotland’s consultation on proposals to improve the out of home food environment.“The proposals, which include consideration of portion sizes, calorie information on the menus, improving quality of food sold out of home, and shting marketing and promotion strategies from unhealthy products to healthier options, offer important steps in the solution to tackle overweight and obesity.”Jonathon Clark, owner of Clarks bakery in the city, said he would comply with any new rules but did not think mandatory calorie labelling “makes much sense”.He said: “We have a salad bar at the front of our shops and have tried to promote healthier eating in our shops.“I don’t think it makes much sense - somebody wants to eat something healthy they’ll make it themselves at home.“If it’s a rainy day then we are at our busiest as people want comfort food.”The proposal has emerged just weeks after American chain Fatburger opened a branch on Dundee’s Reform Street.The business is famed for its quadruple Fatburger challenge, comprising a meaty tower of four burgers sandwiched in a brioche bun with mustard, relish, onion, pickles, tomato, lettuce and mayonnaise. Heather Peace, Head of public health nutrition at Food Standards Scotland said: “We are delighted that Dundee City Council are planning to take part in our Out of Home consultation.“We would also encourage other organisations and consumers to have their say so we can gather as many views as possible before the consultation ends on  February to inform our Out of Home Strategy.”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: brian monteith think the unthinkable nicola s on the way out
story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...The SNP is losing its nerve. Why can we tell this is happening  Simple, #because we are at last #seeing the symptoms of decay in its once strict internal discipline.SNP politicians briefing against each other, hostile opposition to official policy, histrionics about BBC bias as a deflection from what’s going wrong with the party’s strategy and policies – and now even the open talk of notNicola Sturgeon should go, but when and where to.I am not making this up. There is no conspiracy. You only need to have been reading, watching or listening to the news to see the SNP is imploding.Firstly, let’s get the Salmond dficulty out the road. Whatever happens with the pending Alex Salmond prosecution it has caused deep isions around competing loyalties within the SNP. Supporters of the ­Salmond or Sturgeon tribes have been briefing against each other. Were Alex Salmond to be cleared of everything, such behaviour will not be forgotten and of course he could be expected to seek re-election. What then for Sturgeon, what then for the SNP  More bitterness, manoeuvring and ision. Let’s not kid ourselves, the SNP will never be the same again, either because of something Alex Salmond might have done, orinnocent, because of the way Nicola Sturgeon has handled the accusations and process – or a mixture of both.Then we have policies like the Car Park Tax. It will be unjust, having no sense in regard to who pays it, who is given a free pass and whether or not they can afford it. The earnings of the driver or the size of car will not ­matter. And, get this, there will be VAT on top of the tax – because the tax will be a bill presented by the employer providing a serviceand so it attracts  per cent VAT on top. £ would become £, or £ would become £.I also have it on good authority that the tax was offered by the SNP to the Greens as a bribe to get their support for the budget – not the other way round. So it is an SNP Car Park Tax that the party cannot escape blame for.No wonder some SNP politicians are openly letting it be known they do not agree with it – it will cost them votes and cost the party seats in Holyrood.That never used to happen, but discipline has gone out of the window under Nicola Sturgeon’s autocratic husband and we rule. Where  in the Western world does so much power rest in a married couple ­holding the posts of party chief executive and Government leader  Not Romania, not the Philippines. Then there have been the protests about an audience member who gave the SNP Culture Secretary a roasting on BBC’s Question Time. The ­programme makers and the BBC have been accused of bias. This is a ­classic deflection of seeking to take away from and avoid discussing the home truths the member of the public made about SNP hypocrisy. Secondly, the man’s politics, religion, allegiances and number of appearances are all irrelevant – are SNP politicians and fellow travellers saying he should not be allowed to speak, that he should have duct tape over his mouth  Is that what an independent Scotland would be like  We also have growing speculation on Nicola Sturgeon being replaced as leader or retiring before she is served notice. Now that’s a new development, partly fuelled by yet another trip to the United States when the real day job of fixing our schools and hospitals is here at home. Is she being lined up for a job at the UN  Who knows, but the fact that I can even ask the question without sounding foolish tells you the SNP is no longer a happy ship.©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: scottish independence top law officer refuses to reveal if nicola sturgeon asked for indyref2 advice
story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...Scotland#s top law officer has refused to revealNicola Sturgeon has sought his legal advice on holding a second referendum on Scottish independence.Lord Advocate James Wolffe says it would “not be appropriate” even to say whether such advice has been sought in response to Liberal Democrat Mike Rumbles.The MSP has now written to Scotland’s Standards Commissioner calling for an overhaul of parliamentary rulesto force the minister to answer such questions.The refusal has prompted anger because the SNP had been calling for Theresa May to release her legal advice on Brexit.Read more: Nicola Sturgeon: I won’t call a second Scottish independence vote this yearFirst Minister Nicola Sturgeon has pledged to set out her plans for a second vote on Scotland’s future in the UK in the coming weeks. The prospect of a “wildcat” vote being held without authority from Westminster - which has control over the constitution - was at the centre of Mr Rumbles inquiries.The Scottish Government has already refused to answer this and Mr Rumbles sought answers from the Lord Advocate, who is also a minister in the Government.But he has told Mr Rumbles in a response this week that such advice is “privileged and confidential.”“There is well-established convention, long pre-dating devolution, that governments do not identy the matters on which they have taken legal advice from their law officers,” the latter states.“It would not be appropriate for me to disclose whether I have advised or might advise the Government on the matters identied in your letter.”Mr Rumbles has now written to the Scottish Parliament’s Standards, Procedures and Public Appointments Committee to ask them to consider changes to standing orders to allow MSPs to get answers to simple questions, including making it easier for the Lord Advocate to respond to MSPs.“The SNP worked alongside Liberal Democrats when we successfully pressed the UK Government to release their Brexit legal advice,” Mr Rumbles said.“People will wonder why the SNP Government are refusing to put their own independence plans through the same openness test.“The Scottish Government are going to outrageous s to avoid telling the public what they are plotting behind closed doors. Ministers just shuffle excuses back and forward between themselves.”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: snp adviser calls for softest of all form of scottish independence
story: A key economic adviser to Nicola Sturgeon has called for the #softest of all# forms of independence in order to win a Yes vote.Andrew Wilson, who penned the recently revised economic blueprint for an independent Scotland - the Sustainable Growth Commission - says this is the way to “win big.”But the ex-SNP MSP’s comments prompted criticism from pro-union parties who insisted there is “no such thing” as soft independence.Ms Sturgeon has pledged to set out her timetable for a second referendum in the coming weeks. The pro-independence campaign has faced increasingly awkward questions over the practicalities of leaving a centuries old union, in light of the turmoil engulfing the UK over its looming departure from the EU.: Law officer refuses to revealSturgeon asked for indyref adviceBut Mr Wilson sought to play down such concerns in his weekly column for the national newspaper today.“In the parlance of Brexit, we offer the softest of possible changes to the current arrangements, not the hardest,” he said.“We recognise the level of integration and all the ties that have bound us for centuries. We create a  that can uny a majority for progress that stands a chance of winning and winning big.”Mr Wilson’s prospectus set out plans for caps in public spending in the early years of independence to address Scotland’s deficit and warned against a more radical outlook within the Nationalist movement.He added: “Somewould rather move immediately and overnight to a Marxist revolutionary state. That is their right, but they won’t win the chance to try.”But Pamela Nash, chief executive of Scotland in Union, said: “There is no such thing as soft independence.“Independence would involve breaking up the most successful union the world has ever seen, building barriers between families, friends and neighbours.“It would ide our home market, jeopardising our economy, and lead to further and deeper austerity.”Labour’s finance spokesman James Kelly added: “The author of the so-called Growth Commission can try and rebrand leaving the UK however he likes, but in reality his plans mean another decade of austerity for Scotland and an economic model that works for big business, not workers.”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: first look at the jarls squad
story: Plenty of onlookers were already on the streets as the squad made its first procession of the day from Islesburgh Community Centre, past the galley shed on St Sunniva Street and on to the Toll Clock Shopping Centre.In the gloom, the ranks of the Jarl#s Squad looked the part wearing emerald green kirtles with dragon mots underneath simple brown leather breastplates embossed with the same mot. A animal skin cloak completes the look. the suit was very warm, a blessing on a day like today.If the breastplate is simple that is in contrast to the fierce-looking helmets which are designed to look like a dragon#s head, complete with #scales# hanging from the back of the helmets.Squad member Lynden Nicolson has spent hours working on the helmets and said he was thrilled with the way they had turned out. title: halcro johnston welcomes comments from senior snp minister on ferry funding
story: Signs have emerged of a softening in the Scottish government#s approach to fair ferry funding, with one Tory MSP insisting a senior SNP colleague has given backing for a better deal on leline links.Isles councillors have been left frustrated by the Scottish government#s funding offer following its budget, not least because of a shortfall in ferry funding.Complaints have been made by island leaders that the funding settlement, agreed last year, does not meet the full costs of running the internal ferries in Orkney and in Shetland.In the Western Isles the costs are met by the Scottish government as part of Clyde and Hebridean ferry service contract.But Conservative MSP Jamie Halcro Johnston had highlighted a visit to Orkney by the SNP #s constitutional relations secretary, Mike Russell.Jamie Halcro JohnstonAccording to a news release dispatched on Thursday, Mr Russell told The Orcadian newspaper: “I can take that back, and I can say to my colleagues, look this is a big issue in Orkney, and obviously it needs a resolution”.Mr Halcro Johnston welcomed the cabinet secretary’s acknowledgement that a resolution was required and urged one to be brought forward.“I welcome news of Mike Russell’s comments on fair ferry funding, and I’m encouraged by the intervention of a senior SNP minister. As a representative for Argyll and Bute, Mr Russell clearly understands ferry issues rather better than some of his government colleagues.#It comes after the Scottish government agreed to alter its spending plans with support from the Scottish Greens.The Greens said the Scottish government had agreed to alter its spending plans in exchange for support in getting the budget through.SIC leader Steven Coutts told The Shetland Times on Thursday: #At the moment we#re still waiting to see the final full detail on the back of the deal that was done between the Green Party and the SNP. We need to see what the figures actually mean.#There#s still no commitment on full and fair ferry funding, and that#s something we#ll want to press the government and Green Party on.#..

title: council adjourns decision on viking energy
story: A meeting to determine whether the council will object to an application to increase the size of the turbines which would form the Viking Energy windfarm has been adjourned amid confusion among members.The firm is seeking permission to increase the height of the proposed  turbines by  metres to a maximum of  metres.The Scottish government will have the final say on whether the project goes ahead but councillors met on Wednesday afternoon to discuss whether the local authority would, as a formal consultee, object to the application.Councillors expressed dismay saying that it was unclear which new or modied conditions were being considered. Those matters already determined in  and  were not under the microscope.Lerwick South councillor Cecil Smith said that he also felt uncomfortable that this decision was being taken by the council#s planning committee, with just a handful of members present, as opposed to the full council.However, he was informed that a decision had to be made within  hoursthe council were to fulfil its duty as a statutory consultee.Meanwhile, Shetland South member George Smith said that he wanted a new report brought before the council which made it clear what specic issues were relevant to the ied consent application.Councillor Catherine Hughson asked whether an extension could be granted to allow the council further time to consider its response.The meeting was adjourned to allow the council#s corporate services executive manager Jan Riise to seek clarity on this issue.. raquo Let us be very careful about what we approve, for an astonishingly beautul wilderness.Alan Skinner..
